TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Alabaster clay - on a 1 percent slope in an idle field.  (colors are for moist soil unless otherwise stated.)
Ap--0 to 9 inches; 80 percent very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) clay, light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) dry; 20 percent dark brown (7.5YR 4/4) B horizon material; strong medium subangular blocky structure; friable; few medium and common fine and very fine roots; slightly effervescent; moderately alkaline; abrupt smooth boundary.  (9 to 11 inches thick)
Bw1--9 to 13 inches; brown (7.5YR 5/4) clay; moderate medium prismatic structure parting to strong fine angular blocky; firm; few fine to coarse roots; common distinct grayish brown (10YR 5/2) skeletans on vertical ped faces; many medium prominent brownish yellow (10YR 6/6) iron accumulations and many fine prominent greenish gray (5GY 6/1) and many fine distinct reddish brown (5YR 5/3) iron depletions; strongly effervescent; moderately alkaline; clear smooth boundary.  (0 to 4 inches thick)
Bw2--13 to 17 inches; reddish brown (5YR 4/3) clay; strong medium prismatic structure parting to strong medium and coarse platy; firm; few fine to common roots; many distinct grayish brown (10YR 5/2) and gray (10YR 6/1) skeletans on horizontal and vertical ped faces; few distinct pinkish gray (7.5YR 7/2) lime coats on horizontal and vertical ped faces; common medium prominent yellowish brown (10YR 5/6) iron accumulations and common fine prominent greenish gray (5GY 6/1) iron depletions; violently effervescent; moderately alkaline; clear smooth boundary.  (0 to 4 inches thick)
BC--17 to 32 inches; reddish brown (5YR 4/3) clay; strong medium and coarse prismatic structure parting to strong medium angular blocky; firm; common distinct gray (10YR 6/1) skeletans on horizontal and vertical ped faces;  few distinct white (10YR 8/1) lime coats on vertical ped faces; common medium prominent yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) iron accumulations and many fine prominent greenish gray (5G 6/1) iron depletions; violently effervescent; moderately alkaline; clear wavy boundary. (0 to 17 inches thick)
C--32 to 80 inches; reddish brown (5YR 5/3) clay; strong medium and coarse prismatic structure parting to strong fine and medium angular blocky; firm; many distinct light gray (N 7/0) skeletans on vertical and horizontal ped faces; few distinct white (7.5YR 8/0) lime coats on vertical ped faces; common medium prominent reddish yellow (7.5YR 6/6) iron accumulations; violently effervescent; moderately alkaline.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:   Iosco County, Michigan; about 4 miles southwest of Tawas City; 1300 feet south and 120 feet east of the northwest corner of section 22, T. 21 N., R. 7 E.; USGS topo quandrangle Alabaster, Michigan; lat. 44 degrees 12 minutes 11 seconds N. and long. 84 degrees 34 minutes 53 seconds W.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: COMPETING SERIES: There are no competing series.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  The Alabaster soils are found on lake plains.  The slopes range from 0 to 3 percent. The mean annual precipitation ranges from 28 to 30 inches and mean annual temperature is about 43 to 45 degrees F.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS: These are the somewhat poorly drained Allendale soils and the poorly drained Springport soils.  Allendale soils occur on higher positions in the landscape.  Springport soils occur on lower positions in the landscape.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Somewhat poorly drained. These soils have a perched seasonal high water table that ranges from .5 to 1.5 feet below the surface at some time during the the period from October to May.  Surface runoff is slow.  Permeability is very slow.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  A large percentage is used for growing hay; minor crops are corn and small grains.  Other areas are used for pastureland or are idle.

REGIONAL OFFICE.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Northeastern lower Michigan the series is small in extent.

ORIGIN.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
ORIGIN.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: AMHERST, MASSACHUSETTS

REMARKS.content: SERIES PROPOSED:  Iosco County, Michigan, 1993.  The source of the name is a ghost town in Iosco County.
